headline: Laura Ingraham on CDC updating mask guidance for vaccinated Americans

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right. I'm Laura Ingraham. This is the "Ingraham Angle" from Washington. Tonight the "Ingraham Angle" features a tale of two cities. Our nation's capital in all its beauty versus a special city in South Florida. Plus, could Virginia's gubernatorial race this November prove to be a bellwether for a Republican resurgence nationwide. GOP candidate Glenn Youngkin is here to tell us about it. But first, Biden's shiny objects. That's the focus of tonight's "Angle". I've always been kind of fascinated by the possibility of what time travel would be like. What would it really be like to cross dimensions?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Precisely. And now it's official. It doesn't just happen in the movies though, or as Biden calls them, the talkies. His administration screwed up all the priorities. And of course, Americans now and at least a dozen states along the eastern seaboard are feeling the pinch with gasoline. They're living like it's like "The Wonder Years" of the mid to late 70s.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All of us must learn to waste less energy, simply by keeping our thermostats for instance, at 65 degrees in the daytime and 55 degrees at night, we could save half the current shortage of natural gas. If we learn to live thriftily and remember the importance of helping our neighbors, then we can find ways to adjust.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Now fast forward to today, and you see the same problems. The colonial pipeline is back online, but it will take several days for supplies to return to normal. And even then, Biden's response to all of this, his priorities have made us more vulnerable to future cyberattacks.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: For more on the ransom, were you briefed on the fact that the company did pay the ransom?

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I have no comment on that. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: No comment on that. What about the ransom, Joe? Again, if they paid ransom, and we're more susceptible to future hacks, whatever, come on, does it really matter? Remember, as his Energy Secretary sniped, "If you drove a Tesla, you wouldn't be racing around to gas stations trying to fill up", paraphrasing there. Jennifer Gran, go home. Well, the fact is, it's painfully obvious that Democrats and their media flunkies are totally disinterested in solving the problems facing Middle America, because if you drive less because gas is too high. Good, they hate your big SUVs anyway. And if you have fewer kids, because the cost of living is so high. Good, they hate big families. And by the way, if the cost of guns is prohibitive, and there is a shortage of ammo. Good, they want to gut the Second Amendment. And if you're worried about more crime and less police. Too bad, it's all the cops fault anyway. They're racist. Now, it's not that the liberals don't have their priorities. Oh, they do. And one of them and one of their tactics is to distract you with irrelevant sideshows.

utterances.speaker: SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: To be a leader in the Republican Party right now, do you have to buy the lie?

utterances.speaker: REP. LIZ CHENEY (R-WY)
utterances.sentences: I think it's important for those of us who refuse to do that to be willing to stand up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The Republican rationalizations for demonizing her dissent are part of a long pattern of caving to extremists for short-term political gain.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is a sad and dark moment.

utterances.speaker: JOY BEHAR, ABC HOST
utterances.sentences: She is the Joan of Arc standing up to the heretics.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I'd rather than governing as responsible adults. You know what Biden promised us, all that calm and responsible leadership. His party in their calm shop, well, they hope to skate over all those problems by traveling back to January 6.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Some Republicans tried to rewrite the history of January 6.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It is traumatic to watch that video.

utterances.speaker: REP. TIM RYAN (R-OH)
utterances.sentences: Our Republican friends are looking the other way here. They want to sweep this thing under the rug.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We know that there were extremist groups that were part of that mob.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: This is the vision they want you to keep front and center. They want you to fear Mr. Furball in face paint more than the fact that your dollar is going to be worth less and less and less in the coming weeks and months. Liberals in leadership in their state media, they may not be fretting about an increasingly volatile Middle East, but they are actively monitoring the real conflicts that matter.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You had an interaction between Marjorie Taylor Greene and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. Do you have concerns about what January 6th has done to the relationships here on the Hill?

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
utterances.sentences: Probably it's a matter for the ethics committee. This is beneath the dignity of a person serving in the Congress of the United States. And it's a cause for trauma and fear among members, especially on the heels of an insurrection.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I love this hand gesture of hers. Of course, what they really fear is that her house of card is about to come tumbling down. Of course, with everything that's happening with the economy, they're worried, all right. So they want you to just wish all your money was away. So when the troubling new data on inflation came out, "The Washington Post" quickly sprung into action with this chart. Inflation even tamer after removing the effects of volatile gasoline and food prices. Oh, don't worry about that. Come on, don't worry about it. It's only food and fuel. You don't spend any money on that, right. And today, Jen Psaki followed up with this absurd spin.

utterances.speaker: JEN PSAKI, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: Obviously, we've seen over the last couple of days, to your point, some reaction to the CPI numbers that came out just yesterday. Our view on that as it reflects the reality of an economy that's rapidly turning back on because of a successful economic strategy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: A successful economic strategy Joey Carter has. Now right now, Americans at all income levels have less money in their pockets and less freedom to move about and to travel. Because this was the Democrats' plan all along. I'm not talking about the pipeline hack, but their policies to clamp down on drilling and to cancel the Keystone Pipeline. If you have to suffer because of those policies, so be it.

utterances.speaker: REP. ELEANOR HOLMES NORTON (D-DC)
utterances.sentences: We're investing not only in Russia to reduce automobile usage, but also we're investing in pedestrian and bicycle infrastructure, if you really want to reduce. We really want to get a climate change.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: DC is already a tangle of bike infrastructure by the way. They made traffic even worse by cutting off access near the Black Lives Matter Plaza as well. It all looks like a dystopian disaster down there. We'll get to it in a moment. But they got what they wanted in DC. They got less traffic, along with less prosperity, less business activity, fewer tourists, fewer workers. No one's going back to their offices. It's just great in liberal la la land. So again, they have their priorities. But they're sure not your priorities. Wait, wait, but to be fair, there [ph] PIO priorities do include an infrastructure plan. I want to be clear about that. And it does involve building, all right. But it's building a country that you don't recognize and that you don't want to live in. And that's the "Angle". All right. Joining me now Florida congressman Byron Donalds, and House Minority Whip Steve Scalise. Congressman Scalise, these shiny objects game of the Democrats focusing on January 6 and Furman are focusing on AOC's spat with Marjorie Taylor Greene, this is as people can't find gasoline in major American cities and suburbs all across the eastern seaboard. How is this making any sense?

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE (R-LA)
utterances.sentences: Yes. Laura, what you're seeing right here with the Biden administration is a group of people that are weighing over their heads. I mean, look at all around the world. It's on fire. You've got Israel under attack tonight. You got lines at the gas pump. It's like the 70s. Jimmy Carter probably wouldn't want to be compared to this administration. Inflation's through the roof. Look lumber prices, probably 400 percent up. Many schools are still close where kids can't even get an education, and Joe Biden siding with the teachers unions instead of children in America, millions of who may never recover from what he is doing to them. On every front, we're seeing disaster and crisis at the border after crisis. And this president, it's like he shows up for about two hours, he can't answer any questions and then he goes away. And they just hope that they can throw shiny objects to distract the American people. But people are getting fed up, they're seeing this. They're very concerned about this direction, the socialist move by Pelosi and Biden.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Congressman Donalds, Pelosi did make a pitch for this so-called infrastructure bill of Biden's. Watch.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.sentences: The country needs a strong infrastructure package. It's an issue of clean air, it's an issue of quality of life for people to have them out of their cars with more mass transit and the rest.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Congressman, she has the gall to say that she wants people "out of their cars", as so many Americans are now suffering because of this gas shortage and their plans for perhaps future gas shortages.

utterances.speaker: REP. BYRON DONALDS (R-FL)
utterances.sentences: I'm not listening to Nancy Pelosi. She was busy getting her hair done while salons were sat down in the state of California. But let's be very clear. Americans want a couple of things. They just want to get back to work, they want their schools reopened, they want the economy restored. They don't want this green policy agenda, they don't want these liberal crazy policies, which have frankly opened up our southern border, have created the gas lines like the leader has talked about, like the whip has talked about, excuse me, Steve, don't want to give you a promotion quite yet because you're going to get it soon. But let's be very clear, their policies are a disaster, and they have to own it. That's why they want to distract us with all this other stuff that doesn't matter to the American people.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Congressman Scalise, Joe Biden wants the best of both worlds, right. He wants to take credit for Operation Warp Speed and for the economy that was recovering under the last quarter when Trump urged everybody to reopen. So, he wants to take credit for that. But he doesn't want to take any responsibility for what's happening with this inflation. So, he was in full spin mode today. Watch.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We've gone from stagnation to an economy that's growing faster than it has in nearly 40 years. We've gone from an anemic job creation to a record for job creation. All of this is a product of prompt action to roll- out the vaccine and boost our economy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Congressman, we are on the verge of an inflationary spiral if they keep using stimulus when no stimulus is needed, clearly.

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.sentences: Yes, we're seeing a deficit of reality in the Biden administration. I mean, if you look on the vaccine front, when Joe Biden took the oath of office, there were three vaccines. Two already approved, one about to be approved, that's now allowed over 200 vaccinations to be put in the arms of Americans. Joe Biden is talking about giving away not just the vaccine, but the entire technology, the mRNA technology to China for free. You are talking about intellectual property theft from China, Joe Biden is going to give it to China. He inherited the hottest economy we've ever seen. He's talking about raising taxes right now that would kill middle-class jobs. And oh, by the way, Laura, today there's over 8 million job openings and Joe Biden is paying people, borrowing from our kids to pay people not to work. It's probably the biggest reason why you have to wait in line to get anything from a refrigerator to a new car.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Yes. Before we go, CNN's Manu Raju tweeted something earlier today saying, "Speaker Pelosi told him "No, she isn't changing the rule requiring masks on the House floor". No, Pelosi said. Wait, are they all vaccinated? Quick response from both of you. Should masks go on the floor of the House and she apparently wants your medical records.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Should have been gone months ago. Most of the members either been vaccinated, or they have antibodies. It is a dumb rule to have.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right. Congressman Scalise, what about you?

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.sentences: Look, she let Joe Biden take his mask off at the stately union address, and she wants everybody else to keep the mask on. Just returned to sanity. Look at states like Florida who are actually doing things right. They actually have a much lower death rate from COVID than states like New York who shut everything down and are keeping kids locked out of school and they're losing a generation now as well as every small business.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I don't mean to interrupt, but you're missing the point. I'm sorry. What she wants to do is shame any member of Congress who made a personal decision not to get the vaccine for whatever reason. That's what that's about. It's not - she doesn't think she's going to get COVID or any of you are going to get COVID. It's a shaming device. So she's trying to shame anyone and perhaps to watch out medical records.

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.sentences: And it's about controller, she wants to control the House, she wants to keep the public out of the people's house by the way too. The American people are done with all of the shut-ins. They want to see their government in action. They want to see their government working for them, which has not happened in the last six months.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right. Congressmen, thank you so much. Great to see both of you tonight. And in their quest to take down floor Florida Governor Ron DeSantis. The media embraced this so-called whistleblower named Rebekah Jones. Remember her? She alleged a vast conspiracy by DeSantis' administration to cover up the severity of COVID. There's one just problem about that. None of it was true. Fox chief breaking news correspondent Trace Gallagher is live now with a story trace.

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, CHIEF BREAKING NEWS CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: Laura, good evening. Rebekah Jones is not a doctor, not an epidemiologist, not even a health expert. She is apparently very tech savvy and is the former manager of Florida's COVID-19 dashboard, you know the program that tracks cases, hospitalizations and deaths. She is also a self-proclaimed whistleblower who alleged without evidence that Florida had under counted COVID-19 deaths claiming her superiors instructed her to alter raw data so that Florida's COVID response would look better. And of course, anything that might make Florida Governor Ron DeSantis look bad is immediately embraced by the liberal media. Watch.

utterances.speaker: REBEKAH JONES, FORMER DATA SCIENTIST, FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
utterances.sentences: This is just a very thinly veiled attempt of the governor to intimidate scientists and get back at me while trying to get to my sources as he's been firing DOH staff left and right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Except as the National Review's Charles C.W. Cooke has reported, Jones doesn't have the power to alter raw numbers on the COVID dashboard quoting here, "Were this charge true, it would reflect one of the most breathtaking political scandals in all of American history." But it's not true, indeed it's nonsense from start to finish. And while Jones couldn't manipulate the dashboard, she did crash it and locked her supervisor out, which ended up getting her fired and having her home raided by police. Jones says this about police quoting, "They pointed a gun in my face. They pointed guns at my kids." "They claimed it was about a security breach. This was DeSantis. He sent the Gestapo." But as we showed you body cam video, does not show police pointing guns at anyone. Rebekah Jones, you should know, has been charged with serious computer crimes. Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: That story takes my breath away. Trace, thank you. Unbelievable. Now the Commonwealth of Virginia has become ground zero for battles between race baiting educators and concerned parents. One of those parents is here next. Plus, how does this poisonous curricula factor into the governor's race next year - this year. Republican Gubernatorial Candidate Glenn Youngkin tells us in moments.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: If there is one state that is perhaps due for a political shift to the right, it's the Commonwealth of Virginia. Over the past year, we've seen parents in affluent Northern Virginia suburbs turn on the Democrats. Now when the schools were shut down for ridiculous amounts of time, some of them are still aren't fully, fully operational, parents rose up to challenge the closures and to take on the unions. And once some schools reopened, those parents then had to contend with the obscene critical race theory that's poisoning their kids' curriculum. And now parents are learning of a new perversion, anti-racist books laden with vulgar and sexually explicit content. Now, parents in Loudoun County were so disgusted by this, they stormed a school board meeting and read aloud the filth that's being pushed on their kids.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: "I kept dancing lost in the music until some bully pushed me up behind me holding my hips and I froze. Looking to Megan for help, she nodded and mouthed, "It's OK, it's cool. This is what girls do at parties." I told myself and kept dancing with the boy. I couldn't see the alcohol making my waist wind faster". If this is inappropriate for me to read to you, this is inappropriate for our children.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Joining us now, the woman you just saw, Patti Hidalgo Menders, Loudon County parent. Patti, this is suggested reading for ninth graders? And that's, by the way, the tamest of the passages we have for everybody tonight.

utterances.speaker: PATTI HIDALGO MENDERS, LOUDOUN COUNTY PARENT
utterances.sentences: In three high schools here in Loudoun County, there is a list of books that are part of a diversity library that English teachers can select. And in this case, we read from a ninth grade English honors class that made this mandatory reading.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Honors class? There's nothing honorable about that. Now, Patti, one of your fellow concerned parents also read a passage from the book "Monday's Not Coming". Here it is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Me and Monday, we did something. We did do something. He took a deep breath. She sucked my d***. I really didn't want it to happen. It just kind of did.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Again, this is for 13 or 14 year olds, correct?

utterances.speaker: MENDERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It is disgusting. I wouldn't even want to read this myself and they are mandatorily telling our children that for them to pass this class they need to select one of these diverse books.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Yes. I just want to get this so people understand we're not exaggerating this. A Loudoun parent reading an reading an excerpt from another book called "Hashtag Murder Trending". Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Jasper wasn't even my boyfriend, just this dude I did some hacking with once in a while. He was pretty basic-library systems, low security s***. Not my league at all. But he had a big d*** and sometimes a girl just needs a big d***.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Now, Patti, I guess one of these books wasn't actually mandatory. But if it's one of the offerings, that's for sure. And if you said any of this in a professional setting, it would be actually called sexual harassment. They're trying to make some social commentary, or talk about abuse or something, or choices kids have to make. But why is this appropriate in a school setting? And how is this going to advance their knowledge about the great works of Western civilization?

utterances.speaker: MENDERS
utterances.sentences: Well, it started when they took away [ph] Dr. Seuss. They said that he was racist. And then we find out that they allowed the school board, approved these diverse books in our schools and they started with the high school and parents found out about it. But the day that we spoke to the school board, did you know that they approved this diversity library for the middle schoolers? So now, what are we going to expect for the even younger students?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Oh, it's going to get worse and worse. Do you all think ever, maybe it's time not to just go to meetings, but run them? Run for school board? Try to try to take these school boards over? I mean, they do. The left is doing this. And they're just rolling over to critical race theory and alike.

utterances.speaker: MENDERS
utterances.sentences: We've tried different avenues. We've tried, hey, let's have a town hall, so you can tell us exactly what's going on with our children. We've tried - now the new strategy is where we're recalling six of the school board members.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Good.

utterances.speaker: MENDERS
utterances.sentences: We used to accept this kind of behavior. This past Saturday, we probably collected over 1700 signatures. So we're going to continue to collect signatures and recall six of the school board members.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Well, that's progress. I think they are going to run really good people. Patti, thank you. We'll stay on this. And the issue of education gives the Virginia GOP an incredible opening. And with the state gubernatorial election just months away, we wanted to know how the Republican nominee plans to address it. Joining us now Glenn Youngkin, Republican candidate for Virginia Governor. Glenn, good to see you tonight. How big of an issue will this be for your campaign given how accelerated this radicalism has become in our schools in Northern Virginia? And how will you hand it over the next six months?

utterances.speaker: GLENN YOUNGKIN, (R) VIRGINIA GUVERNATORIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: It is just an extraordinary moment in our education system in Virginia. I mean, the McAuliffe-Northam dynasty has been dismantling Virginia schools. And thank goodness for parents. I mean, they're the last line of defense. And we don't see anyone standing up from the McAuliffe-Northam administration actually trying to help them. And in fact, they're the ones doing the dismantling. You can just add to this list, expectations that accelerated math won't be taught anymore up through the 11th grade, that in fact they're going to try to stop awarding advanced diplomas. We're actually going to take the 4th of July and the Pledge of Allegiance out of the list of things that bind us. This is just part of the agenda of the liberal left led by Terry McAuliffe and Ralph Northam. And thank goodness for parents. I mean, I need them to keep saying

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, Democrat - a candidate Terry McAuliffe, who was governor before, he is not serving now but I see what you're doing there. He attacked you on Twitter this week. No surprise there. He said, "Folks, here is the truth: extreme Republicans like Glenn Youngkin want nothing more than to roll back the progress we've made over the past 8 years. They aren't interested in lifting up Virginias, just culture wars and division. It's time to move forward not back." Glenn, so you want to go back to what? The 1950s and you want the culture wars and you're not going to talk about economics or any of these issues? Is that what your campaign is going to do?

utterances.speaker: YOUNGKIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. What I find most amazing is that here's Terry, talking about culture wars, when in fact, they support a school system that is actually teaching the most divisive curriculum, a political agenda and critical race theory. And then all they want to do is actually talk about trying to pin us against a wall based on trying to do the right thing for families, for our kids. I mean, they're the ones actually trying to fight the culture war and our kids sadly are the ones getting hurt. Right now the biggest issue is--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Glenn, I'm sorry to interrupt. But why do this race matter? People are watching from all over the country. Laura, you know, Virginia, it's a Democrat state now. They're not going to win that. But why does this matter in an awful election year and remember what happened in 2009. Real quick.

utterances.speaker: GLENN YOUNGKIN, (R) VIRGINIA GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: This is the year for Virginians to stand up and say no more. We've watched the left liberal agenda in Washington, we've watched it in Richmond for the last two years, and Virginia families are ready just say no. And I have seen this groundswell of support across Virginia where this isn't about Republicans versus Democrats. This is actually Virginians against the left liberal policies that have put Virginia in the ditch, and our kids are suffering as a result. Education will be the top issue in this election this year along with getting our economy open and moving. And the Democrats led by Terry McAuliffe are on the wrong side of this issue once again. And this is, again, not Republicans versus Democrats. This is Virginians against the left liberal policy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: The reason this matters, and that was the question I asked you. The reason this matters is because if you can win in the commonwealth of Virginia, as Democrat as it has become in Fairfax County, which is where all the population is, if you can win in the state, then that is a bellwether, I believe, for what happens in 2022. It will be a wipeout for the Republicans against the Democrats. It often is when the Republican is able to win in an off-year election, as happened in 2009. Glenn, it's great to see you tonight, and we appreciate you being here. Thank you so much. And what does lockdown versus liberty look like in visuals? We took a tour of D.C. today, a city full of boarded-up businesses, homeless encampments, drug abusers on the street, and this is just like feet from the seat of power, even with offenses and the wire all around it. Compare that to where FOX's Lisa Boothe is for us tonight in Miami, Florida. The two sides of the COVID coin, next.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: As you can see here, I'm standing outside of the Clevelander South Beach. It is happening. There are so many people out and about, people eating, listening to music. It is lively. People are walking in the streets. Florida is wide open for business.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Homeless encampments have become commonplace in the nation's capital. As you see her, tents are packed into what was a patch of grass less than one year ago. While this is an onset eyes are for struggling local businesses, it doesn't seem to bother lawmakers who walk past these tent cities every day as they head into work just across the street.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Like many Democrat-controlled areas of the country, Washington D.C. is a city in squalor. Before the pandemic it was bustling with business and tourists. Now it's a shell of its former self. But you really have to see the decline to believe it. So we dispatched one of our producers to document the decay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The U Street Corridor used to be a hub for D.C. nightlife, providing homes to some of the most popular bars and restaurants in the district. But after more than year of strict COVID protocols, the once vibrant neighborhood is a dead zone. Mayor Bowser plans to lift capacity restrictions for all bars and nightclubs in June, but by the looks of these boarded-up buildings, the damage is already done.

utterances.speaker: ANTHONY HARRIS, OWNER, BULLFEATHERS
utterances.sentences: I don't think you understand what we suffer through these kinds of situations. Running a business is a very difficult thing, meeting that payroll every couple of weeks and making the rents and everything else Fred.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Anthony Harris is the owner of Bullfeathers, an iconic bar just blocks from Capitol Hill. He's been in the business for 53 years.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It has been very, very difficult for us, with the price of doing business, the overhead has gotten even higher. I think inflation is setting in on a few of our food prices. So it's been very difficult for us. We're only at 25 percent seating, and in this business, 25 percent doesn't cut it. The local government is going to increase the percentages up to full bore eventually, I believe, the 21st of this month.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Do you wish this would've happened sooner?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: My goodness gracious, yes. We're hanging on by threads, for heaven's sake. And at this point of my life, I don't want to invest a lot more money into the business because I have to think how I'm going to live the rest of my life if these places fold on us.

utterances.speaker: KELSEY WOBBLETON, MANAGER, TORTILLA COAST
utterances.sentences: This is the hardest year we've ever had here. It's definitely been hard to keep the motivation to stay open for a while.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Just two doors down at Tortilla Coast, a D.C. staple, manager Kelsey Wobbleton said it's been tough to stay afloat.

utterances.speaker: WOBBLETON
utterances.sentences: That's probably been our biggest struggle is staffing, so we've got interviews, people come in, and about I would say 50 percent actually show up are interested in the job. A lot of those people that used to work in the restaurant industry, they are now pursuing different careers.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What's also hurting businesses in Washington D.C. is the lack of tourism. It went down significantly during COVID, with some experts estimating it will take years to recover.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: There's restrictions that weren't here before, and fell a little, almost like you're doing something wrong if you are coming up here. Everything is closed. You've got the museums, people come to the museums, there's no museums. A lot less people, a lot less restaurants that are open.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It feels more shutdown, because before I left San Francisco, we went out to eat inside restaurants. So lots of people are vaccinated back home. I'm sure they are here, too, but it just feels a little more shut down indoors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Is it different from what you into anticipated?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Different for me, for sure, because I've been here. So I was not expecting that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Would you recommend friends or family members visit D.C. right now?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No. I would tell them wait.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Wow. Let's compare that bleak picture to what life is like in free American cities. So we go live to South Beach in Miami, Florida, were lucky FOX News contributor Lisa Boothe is standing by. Now Lisa, it's absolutely a lively night out there tonight. Tell us what you found, what you're experiencing.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: It is. And I'm so lucky to live here. It's just the complete opposite of what we just heard. Bars, restaurants, nightclubs, all open for business. I don't know if you can hear. The music is blaring next to me. Down the street is absolutely packed. People walking up and down. And I spent the day talking to folks who came here from across the country, many from cities and states that are more locked down, and they said they came here for just a little taste of freedom that they're not getting back home. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Coming from Chicago is it nice to be in a more free environment?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hell, yes. It feels like 100 percent right now. It feels so good to be out. I am wearing a tank top and shorts and no mask at all. Everywhere it feels safe, it feels good. It feels good to be back to normal. And that's how it should be.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's just really amazing to me how the world could just shut down just like that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If we were still locked down, everything would go to --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's been a whole year already. We've already been doing this for so long. I just feel like, how is it not done yet?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It feels like the old. Obviously, it's not the same, but it feels good. I'm glad everything is getting back to open, and people can have fun again.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Is it time to reopen the country?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Are you glad you're visiting here versus maybe a place like D.C. or back in New York where things are pretty closed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Part of the reason we came here was because everything is open and it's great.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Do you feel free and Florida right now?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Are you guys glad that you're in Florida versus --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Do you guys feel free here in Florida?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's way more free out here.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's so much better out here, honestly.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: So Laura, as you heard there, so many people from California, New York, Chicago, just talking about how things just aren't the same there. Life has not been the same. Here is so different, wide open, free, so many people out and about just living their life.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: You forget, Lisa, you forget when you live in a place like D.C. like I live, you forget what the rest of the country is like. You really can forget freedom if you don't fight to reclaim it. You just get used to it. While 72 percent of the country says they are still going to socially distance even when they get the vaccine, at least for six months, according to that recent full. I read that and I almost fell over.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: So much of it doesn't make sense, either. You can get on a plane, but you can take off your mask when you're eating and drinking. So a lot of these rules and regulations, they don't make sense. I think people are ready to live their lives again. I was in New York City earlier this week. It felt so different, felt so dreary. People seemed depressed there. Here everyone is happy, living life, enjoying life, because life is meant to be lived.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Lisa, thanks for that hard assignment down there with all the fun people. That looked like a fun group.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I will do it again, Laura, any time.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right, I got it.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Any time.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Thanks so much, Lisa. And speaking of the mask issue, the CDC's big announcement today was heralded by Biden as a big win, but what science is clear now that wasn't clear a month ago, and for many of us like a year ago. Why doesn't this go far enough? Dr. Jay Bhattacharya is here next. He's going to answer those questions.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Did you see this today? Biden and the poodles in the media, they want you to think that it's somehow a huge victory that the CDC is now saying that if you're vaccinated, you can actually drop your mask, OK. But here is my question. Has the science really changed in the last month? Of course, it hasn't. In fact, it was just a couple of days ago, right, that Fauci was spewing his usual nonsense.

utterances.speaker: DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, BIDEN CHIEF MEDICAL ADVISER
utterances.sentences: I think people have gotten used to the fact that wearing masks clearly, if you look at the data, diminishes respiratory diseases. We have had practically a nonexistent flu season this year merely because people we're doing the kinds of public health things that were directed predominately against COVID-19.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: It's completely false. Here is what the CDC own research says. CDC is not aware of any randomized controlled trials that show that masks or double masks, or a clothed face coverings are effective against COVID- 19. That is in response to a FOIA request of the CDC. Joining me now, Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, Stanford University professor of medicine and epidemiology. Dr. Bhattacharya, this mask thing has been a charade from almost day one. Fauci actually was right the first time he said that it might make people feel a little better, maybe a little around the edges, but that wasn't going to be a key tool in ending the pandemic. So what about this new announcement today?

utterances.speaker: DR. JAY BHATTACHARYA, STANFORD UNIVERSITY EPIDEMIOLOGIST
utterances.sentences: In a sense it was a good first step, but I have no idea why it's taken this long. They should have told people that are vaccinated that they didn't need the mask to begin with. It's amazing. And as a result, they created vaccine hesitancy. They signaled through their behaviors and their words that the vaccines don't work by saying we'll keep wearing masks. So I'm glad they finally did this, and I hope states and businesses take it to heart and get rid of these mask requirements that have done very little good to slow the spread of the disease.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: We've seen kids under the age of 10, I believe, in France never had to wear masks. Sweden, they never mandated masks. Texas, when they dropped their mask mandate, they didn't see any increase in cases. South Dakota never had a mask mandate. So the mask mandate versus non-mask, they showed no difference in the transmission in the states. But Fauci, by the way, still thinks that kids should not really be able to enjoy life unmasked. Watch.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: What is your message to parents who are out there thinking, well, I'm vaccinated, my kids are not, but the odds of them getting the virus are very low. Would you tell them no, no, no, the kids still need to wear a mask?

utterances.speaker: DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, BIDEN CHIEF MEDICAL ADVISER
utterances.sentences: Yes, the children do when they're out there playing with their friends, and particularly in an indoor situation.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Dr. Bhattacharya, is there any real scientific proof that supports Fauci's recommendation that kids would still be in masks?

utterances.speaker: BHATTACHARYA
utterances.sentences: No, there is not. Kids spread the disease very inefficiently. Thank God for that. We don't fully understand why, but it's absolutely true. Lots of scientific evidence backs that up. And furthermore, you'll have to balance the potential benefits, which are very low, against the harms to kids. Masking kids potentially harms their emotional and social development. It does not make sense to mask children. We should not be asking them to do that, especially when adults everywhere are going to be taking their masks off as a result of the vaccination campaigns. I think the problem is in public health messaging, when you go far outside what the science is actually saying, you make these confusing kinds of orders, people will stop trusting public health. It has real consequences.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: No one believes them. When people say the CDC says, it's not exactly considered the good housekeeping seal of approval anymore, Dr. Bhattacharya. There is a medical analyst, Leana Wen, over at CNN, who thinks that vaccinated people not wearing masks is somehow extremist.

utterances.speaker: DR. LEANA WEN, CNN MEDICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: I was shocked by this announcement. I think they went from one extreme to another, and the major step that's missing here is how do we know that people are telling the truth? Who is going to be checking to see if others are also vaccinated? So what does that mean, if I'm bringing my son, my four-year-old who is not fully vaccinated, now he's going to be in a grocery store potentially exposed to people who are not vaccinated who could be of danger to him.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Dr. Bhattacharya, she wants vaccine monitoring. She wants a checker of credentials and papers before you can move in this country.

utterances.speaker: BHATTACHARYA
utterances.sentences: It's just bad public health messaging. She's spreading fear were it doesn't belong. Children are incredibly low risk for bad outcomes from this disease. More children died of the flu last year than died of COVID. It's not close. I just don't understand the thinking behind that. If you are an adult and you are scared of COVID and you haven't had COVID before, get vaccinated and you don't have to worry about other people around you being vaccinated or not. If your child is not really at high risk from severe disease from COVID, don't spread fear to your children where it doesn't belong.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Dr. Bhattacharya, great to see you, thank you. And Mayor Pete gets taken to school, how cute. The Last Bite, next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Little Petey had a rough go on the playground this morning.

utterances.speaker: PETE BUTTIGIEG, TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: I don't want to get bogged down in a semantic or philosophical argument over what to call something if it's a good policy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Secretary, come on.

utterances.speaker: BUTTIGIEG
utterances.sentences: These are things the American people want.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Secretary, you might as well just tell me, you know, you need those roads to drive to free college and free childcare.

utterances.speaker: BUTTIGIEG
utterances.sentences: You can organize it around what the lives of human beings in this country are actually like.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Then you could make that to everything under the sun is infrastructure and we should spend $100 trillion and give everything to everyone.

utterances.speaker: BUTTIGIEG
utterances.sentences: We abundantly do have the money because the bill is paid for, right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Right? Wrong. What a lightweight. Gutfeld takes it all from here. Content and Programming Copyright 2021 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. But it's not true, indeed it's nonsense from start to finish. And while Jones couldn't manipulate the dashboard, she did crash it and locked her supervisor out, which ended up getting her fired and having her home raided by police. Jones says this about police quoting, "They pointed a gun in my face. They pointed guns at my kids." "They claimed it was about a security breach. This was DeSantis. He sent the Gestapo." But as we showed you body cam video, does not show police pointing guns at anyone. Rebekah Jones, you should know, has been charged with serious computer crimes. Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That story takes my breath away. Trace, thank you. Unbelievable. Now the Commonwealth of Virginia has become ground zero for battles between race baiting educators and concerned parents. One of those parents is here next. Plus, how does this poisonous curricula factor into the governor's race next year - this year. Republican Gubernatorial Candidate Glenn Youngkin tells us in moments.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: If there is one state that is perhaps due for a political shift to the right, it's the Commonwealth of Virginia. Over the past year, we've seen parents in affluent Northern Virginia suburbs turn on the Democrats. Now when the schools were shut down for ridiculous amounts of time, some of them are still aren't fully, fully operational, parents rose up to challenge the closures and to take on the unions. And once some schools reopened, those parents then had to contend with the obscene critical race theory that's poisoning their kids' curriculum. And now parents are learning of a new perversion, anti-racist books laden with vulgar and sexually explicit content. Now, parents in Loudoun County were so disgusted by this, they stormed a school board meeting and read aloud the filth that's being pushed on their kids.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: "I kept dancing lost in the music until some bully pushed me up behind me holding my hips and I froze. Looking to Megan for help, she nodded and mouthed, "It's OK, it's cool. This is what girls do at parties." I told myself and kept dancing with the boy. I couldn't see the alcohol making my waist wind faster". If this is inappropriate for me to read to you, this is inappropriate for our children.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Joining us now, the woman you just saw, Patti Hidalgo Menders, Loudon County parent. Patti, this is suggested reading for ninth graders? And that's, by the way, the tamest of the passages we have for everybody tonight.

utterances.speaker: PATTI HIDALGO MENDERS, LOUDOUN COUNTY PARENT
utterances.utterance: In three high schools here in Loudoun County, there is a list of books that are part of a diversity library that English teachers can select. And in this case, we read from a ninth grade English honors class that made this mandatory reading.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Honors class? There's nothing honorable about that. Now, Patti, one of your fellow concerned parents also read a passage from the book "Monday's Not Coming". Here it is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Me and Monday, we did something. We did do something. He took a deep breath. She sucked my d***. I really didn't want it to happen. It just kind of did.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Again, this is for 13 or 14 year olds, correct?

utterances.speaker: MENDERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. It is disgusting. I wouldn't even want to read this myself and they are mandatorily telling our children that for them to pass this class they need to select one of these diverse books.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. I just want to get this so people understand we're not exaggerating this. A Loudoun parent reading an reading an excerpt from another book called "Hashtag Murder Trending". Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Jasper wasn't even my boyfriend, just this dude I did some hacking with once in a while. He was pretty basic-library systems, low security s***. Not my league at all. But he had a big d*** and sometimes a girl just needs a big d***.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Now, Patti, I guess one of these books wasn't actually mandatory. But if it's one of the offerings, that's for sure. And if you said any of this in a professional setting, it would be actually called sexual harassment. They're trying to make some social commentary, or talk about abuse or something, or choices kids have to make. But why is this appropriate in a school setting? And how is this going to advance their knowledge about the great works of Western civilization?

utterances.speaker: MENDERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it started when they took away [ph] Dr. Seuss. They said that he was racist. And then we find out that they allowed the school board, approved these diverse books in our schools and they started with the high school and parents found out about it. But the day that we spoke to the school board, did you know that they approved this diversity library for the middle schoolers? So now, what are we going to expect for the even younger students?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, it's going to get worse and worse. Do you all think ever, maybe it's time not to just go to meetings, but run them? Run for school board? Try to try to take these school boards over? I mean, they do. The left is doing this. And they're just rolling over to critical race theory and alike.

utterances.speaker: MENDERS
utterances.utterance: We've tried different avenues. We've tried, hey, let's have a town hall, so you can tell us exactly what's going on with our children. We've tried - now the new strategy is where we're recalling six of the school board members.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Good.

utterances.speaker: MENDERS
utterances.utterance: We used to accept this kind of behavior. This past Saturday, we probably collected over 1700 signatures. So we're going to continue to collect signatures and recall six of the school board members.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, that's progress. I think they are going to run really good people. Patti, thank you. We'll stay on this. And the issue of education gives the Virginia GOP an incredible opening. And with the state gubernatorial election just months away, we wanted to know how the Republican nominee plans to address it. Joining us now Glenn Youngkin, Republican candidate for Virginia Governor. Glenn, good to see you tonight. How big of an issue will this be for your campaign given how accelerated this radicalism has become in our schools in Northern Virginia? And how will you hand it over the next six months?

utterances.speaker: GLENN YOUNGKIN, (R) VIRGINIA GUVERNATORIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: It is just an extraordinary moment in our education system in Virginia. I mean, the McAuliffe-Northam dynasty has been dismantling Virginia schools. And thank goodness for parents. I mean, they're the last line of defense. And we don't see anyone standing up from the McAuliffe-Northam administration actually trying to help them. And in fact, they're the ones doing the dismantling. You can just add to this list, expectations that accelerated math won't be taught anymore up through the 11th grade, that in fact they're going to try to stop awarding advanced diplomas. We're actually going to take the 4th of July and the Pledge of Allegiance out of the list of things that bind us. This is just part of the agenda of the liberal left led by Terry McAuliffe and Ralph Northam. And thank goodness for parents. I mean, I need them to keep saying

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, Democrat - a candidate Terry McAuliffe, who was governor before, he is not serving now but I see what you're doing there. He attacked you on Twitter this week. No surprise there. He said, "Folks, here is the truth: extreme Republicans like Glenn Youngkin want nothing more than to roll back the progress we've made over the past 8 years. They aren't interested in lifting up Virginias, just culture wars and division. It's time to move forward not back." Glenn, so you want to go back to what? The 1950s and you want the culture wars and you're not going to talk about economics or any of these issues? Is that what your campaign is going to do?

utterances.speaker: YOUNGKIN
utterances.utterance: Yes. What I find most amazing is that here's Terry, talking about culture wars, when in fact, they support a school system that is actually teaching the most divisive curriculum, a political agenda and critical race theory. And then all they want to do is actually talk about trying to pin us against a wall based on trying to do the right thing for families, for our kids. I mean, they're the ones actually trying to fight the culture war and our kids sadly are the ones getting hurt. Right now the biggest issue is--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Glenn, I'm sorry to interrupt. But why do this race matter? People are watching from all over the country. Laura, you know, Virginia, it's a Democrat state now. They're not going to win that. But why does this matter in an awful election year and remember what happened in 2009. Real quick.

utterances.speaker: GLENN YOUNGKIN, (R) VIRGINIA GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: This is the year for Virginians to stand up and say no more. We've watched the left liberal agenda in Washington, we've watched it in Richmond for the last two years, and Virginia families are ready just say no. And I have seen this groundswell of support across Virginia where this isn't about Republicans versus Democrats. This is actually Virginians against the left liberal policies that have put Virginia in the ditch, and our kids are suffering as a result. Education will be the top issue in this election this year along with getting our economy open and moving. And the Democrats led by Terry McAuliffe are on the wrong side of this issue once again. And this is, again, not Republicans versus Democrats. This is Virginians against the left liberal policy.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: The reason this matters, and that was the question I asked you. The reason this matters is because if you can win in the commonwealth of Virginia, as Democrat as it has become in Fairfax County, which is where all the population is, if you can win in the state, then that is a bellwether, I believe, for what happens in 2022. It will be a wipeout for the Republicans against the Democrats. It often is when the Republican is able to win in an off-year election, as happened in 2009. Glenn, it's great to see you tonight, and we appreciate you being here. Thank you so much. And what does lockdown versus liberty look like in visuals? We took a tour of D.C. today, a city full of boarded-up businesses, homeless encampments, drug abusers on the street, and this is just like feet from the seat of power, even with offenses and the wire all around it. Compare that to where FOX's Lisa Boothe is for us tonight in Miami, Florida. The two sides of the COVID coin, next.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: As you can see here, I'm standing outside of the Clevelander South Beach. It is happening. There are so many people out and about, people eating, listening to music. It is lively. People are walking in the streets. Florida is wide open for business.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Homeless encampments have become commonplace in the nation's capital. As you see her, tents are packed into what was a patch of grass less than one year ago. While this is an onset eyes are for struggling local businesses, it doesn't seem to bother lawmakers who walk past these tent cities every day as they head into work just across the street.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Like many Democrat-controlled areas of the country, Washington D.C. is a city in squalor. Before the pandemic it was bustling with business and tourists. Now it's a shell of its former self. But you really have to see the decline to believe it. So we dispatched one of our producers to document the decay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The U Street Corridor used to be a hub for D.C. nightlife, providing homes to some of the most popular bars and restaurants in the district. But after more than year of strict COVID protocols, the once vibrant neighborhood is a dead zone. Mayor Bowser plans to lift capacity restrictions for all bars and nightclubs in June, but by the looks of these boarded-up buildings, the damage is already done.

utterances.speaker: ANTHONY HARRIS, OWNER, BULLFEATHERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think you understand what we suffer through these kinds of situations. Running a business is a very difficult thing, meeting that payroll every couple of weeks and making the rents and everything else Fred.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Anthony Harris is the owner of Bullfeathers, an iconic bar just blocks from Capitol Hill. He's been in the business for 53 years.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: It has been very, very difficult for us, with the price of doing business, the overhead has gotten even higher. I think inflation is setting in on a few of our food prices. So it's been very difficult for us. We're only at 25 percent seating, and in this business, 25 percent doesn't cut it. The local government is going to increase the percentages up to full bore eventually, I believe, the 21st of this month.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Do you wish this would've happened sooner?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: My goodness gracious, yes. We're hanging on by threads, for heaven's sake. And at this point of my life, I don't want to invest a lot more money into the business because I have to think how I'm going to live the rest of my life if these places fold on us.

utterances.speaker: KELSEY WOBBLETON, MANAGER, TORTILLA COAST
utterances.utterance: This is the hardest year we've ever had here. It's definitely been hard to keep the motivation to stay open for a while.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Just two doors down at Tortilla Coast, a D.C. staple, manager Kelsey Wobbleton said it's been tough to stay afloat.

utterances.speaker: WOBBLETON
utterances.utterance: That's probably been our biggest struggle is staffing, so we've got interviews, people come in, and about I would say 50 percent actually show up are interested in the job. A lot of those people that used to work in the restaurant industry, they are now pursuing different careers.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: What's also hurting businesses in Washington D.C. is the lack of tourism. It went down significantly during COVID, with some experts estimating it will take years to recover.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: There's restrictions that weren't here before, and fell a little, almost like you're doing something wrong if you are coming up here. Everything is closed. You've got the museums, people come to the museums, there's no museums. A lot less people, a lot less restaurants that are open.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It feels more shutdown, because before I left San Francisco, we went out to eat inside restaurants. So lots of people are vaccinated back home. I'm sure they are here, too, but it just feels a little more shut down indoors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Is it different from what you into anticipated?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Different for me, for sure, because I've been here. So I was not expecting that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Would you recommend friends or family members visit D.C. right now?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: No. I would tell them wait.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Wow. Let's compare that bleak picture to what life is like in free American cities. So we go live to South Beach in Miami, Florida, were lucky FOX News contributor Lisa Boothe is standing by. Now Lisa, it's absolutely a lively night out there tonight. Tell us what you found, what you're experiencing.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: It is. And I'm so lucky to live here. It's just the complete opposite of what we just heard. Bars, restaurants, nightclubs, all open for business. I don't know if you can hear. The music is blaring next to me. Down the street is absolutely packed. People walking up and down. And I spent the day talking to folks who came here from across the country, many from cities and states that are more locked down, and they said they came here for just a little taste of freedom that they're not getting back home. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Coming from Chicago is it nice to be in a more free environment?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Hell, yes. It feels like 100 percent right now. It feels so good to be out. I am wearing a tank top and shorts and no mask at all. Everywhere it feels safe, it feels good. It feels good to be back to normal. And that's how it should be.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's just really amazing to me how the world could just shut down just like that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: If we were still locked down, everything would go to --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It's been a whole year already. We've already been doing this for so long. I just feel like, how is it not done yet?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It feels like the old. Obviously, it's not the same, but it feels good. I'm glad everything is getting back to open, and people can have fun again.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Is it time to reopen the country?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Are you glad you're visiting here versus maybe a place like D.C. or back in New York where things are pretty closed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Part of the reason we came here was because everything is open and it's great.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Do you feel free and Florida right now?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Are you guys glad that you're in Florida versus --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Do you guys feel free here in Florida?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's way more free out here.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It's so much better out here, honestly.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: So Laura, as you heard there, so many people from California, New York, Chicago, just talking about how things just aren't the same there. Life has not been the same. Here is so different, wide open, free, so many people out and about just living their life.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You forget, Lisa, you forget when you live in a place like D.C. like I live, you forget what the rest of the country is like. You really can forget freedom if you don't fight to reclaim it. You just get used to it. While 72 percent of the country says they are still going to socially distance even when they get the vaccine, at least for six months, according to that recent full. I read that and I almost fell over.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: So much of it doesn't make sense, either. You can get on a plane, but you can take off your mask when you're eating and drinking. So a lot of these rules and regulations, they don't make sense. I think people are ready to live their lives again. I was in New York City earlier this week. It felt so different, felt so dreary. People seemed depressed there. Here everyone is happy, living life, enjoying life, because life is meant to be lived.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. Lisa, thanks for that hard assignment down there with all the fun people. That looked like a fun group.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I will do it again, Laura, any time.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right, I got it.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Any time.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Thanks so much, Lisa. And speaking of the mask issue, the CDC's big announcement today was heralded by Biden as a big win, but what science is clear now that wasn't clear a month ago, and for many of us like a year ago. Why doesn't this go far enough? Dr. Jay Bhattacharya is here next. He's going to answer those questions.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Did you see this today? Biden and the poodles in the media, they want you to think that it's somehow a huge victory that the CDC is now saying that if you're vaccinated, you can actually drop your mask, OK. But here is my question. Has the science really changed in the last month? Of course, it hasn't. In fact, it was just a couple of days ago, right, that Fauci was spewing his usual nonsense.

utterances.speaker: DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, BIDEN CHIEF MEDICAL ADVISER
utterances.utterance: I think people have gotten used to the fact that wearing masks clearly, if you look at the data, diminishes respiratory diseases. We have had practically a nonexistent flu season this year merely because people we're doing the kinds of public health things that were directed predominately against COVID-19.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's completely false. Here is what the CDC own research says. CDC is not aware of any randomized controlled trials that show that masks or double masks, or a clothed face coverings are effective against COVID- 19. That is in response to a FOIA request of the CDC. Joining me now, Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, Stanford University professor of medicine and epidemiology. Dr. Bhattacharya, this mask thing has been a charade from almost day one. Fauci actually was right the first time he said that it might make people feel a little better, maybe a little around the edges, but that wasn't going to be a key tool in ending the pandemic. So what about this new announcement today?

utterances.speaker: DR. JAY BHATTACHARYA, STANFORD UNIVERSITY EPIDEMIOLOGIST
utterances.utterance: In a sense it was a good first step, but I have no idea why it's taken this long. They should have told people that are vaccinated that they didn't need the mask to begin with. It's amazing. And as a result, they created vaccine hesitancy. They signaled through their behaviors and their words that the vaccines don't work by saying we'll keep wearing masks. So I'm glad they finally did this, and I hope states and businesses take it to heart and get rid of these mask requirements that have done very little good to slow the spread of the disease.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: We've seen kids under the age of 10, I believe, in France never had to wear masks. Sweden, they never mandated masks. Texas, when they dropped their mask mandate, they didn't see any increase in cases. South Dakota never had a mask mandate. So the mask mandate versus non-mask, they showed no difference in the transmission in the states. But Fauci, by the way, still thinks that kids should not really be able to enjoy life unmasked. Watch.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: What is your message to parents who are out there thinking, well, I'm vaccinated, my kids are not, but the odds of them getting the virus are very low. Would you tell them no, no, no, the kids still need to wear a mask?

utterances.speaker: DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, BIDEN CHIEF MEDICAL ADVISER
utterances.utterance: Yes, the children do when they're out there playing with their friends, and particularly in an indoor situation.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Dr. Bhattacharya, is there any real scientific proof that supports Fauci's recommendation that kids would still be in masks?

utterances.speaker: BHATTACHARYA
utterances.utterance: No, there is not. Kids spread the disease very inefficiently. Thank God for that. We don't fully understand why, but it's absolutely true. Lots of scientific evidence backs that up. And furthermore, you'll have to balance the potential benefits, which are very low, against the harms to kids. Masking kids potentially harms their emotional and social development. It does not make sense to mask children. We should not be asking them to do that, especially when adults everywhere are going to be taking their masks off as a result of the vaccination campaigns. I think the problem is in public health messaging, when you go far outside what the science is actually saying, you make these confusing kinds of orders, people will stop trusting public health. It has real consequences.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No one believes them. When people say the CDC says, it's not exactly considered the good housekeeping seal of approval anymore, Dr. Bhattacharya. There is a medical analyst, Leana Wen, over at CNN, who thinks that vaccinated people not wearing masks is somehow extremist.

utterances.speaker: DR. LEANA WEN, CNN MEDICAL ANALYST
utterances.utterance: I was shocked by this announcement. I think they went from one extreme to another, and the major step that's missing here is how do we know that people are telling the truth? Who is going to be checking to see if others are also vaccinated? So what does that mean, if I'm bringing my son, my four-year-old who is not fully vaccinated, now he's going to be in a grocery store potentially exposed to people who are not vaccinated who could be of danger to him.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Dr. Bhattacharya, she wants vaccine monitoring. She wants a checker of credentials and papers before you can move in this country.

utterances.speaker: BHATTACHARYA
utterances.utterance: It's just bad public health messaging. She's spreading fear were it doesn't belong. Children are incredibly low risk for bad outcomes from this disease. More children died of the flu last year than died of COVID. It's not close. I just don't understand the thinking behind that. If you are an adult and you are scared of COVID and you haven't had COVID before, get vaccinated and you don't have to worry about other people around you being vaccinated or not. If your child is not really at high risk from severe disease from COVID, don't spread fear to your children where it doesn't belong.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Dr. Bhattacharya, great to see you, thank you. And Mayor Pete gets taken to school, how cute. The Last Bite, next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Little Petey had a rough go on the playground this morning.

utterances.speaker: PETE BUTTIGIEG, TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: I don't want to get bogged down in a semantic or philosophical argument over what to call something if it's a good policy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Mr. Secretary, come on.

utterances.speaker: BUTTIGIEG
utterances.utterance: These are things the American people want.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Mr. Secretary, you might as well just tell me, you know, you need those roads to drive to free college and free childcare.

utterances.speaker: BUTTIGIEG
utterances.utterance: You can organize it around what the lives of human beings in this country are actually like.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Then you could make that to everything under the sun is infrastructure and we should spend $100 trillion and give everything to everyone.

utterances.speaker: BUTTIGIEG
utterances.utterance: We abundantly do have the money because the bill is paid for, right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
